Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen flashing with the next number to dial. As a telemarketer, today was the final push—if I didn’t meet my sales quota, not only would I lose my bonus, but the whole team would face penalties. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “Every call counts today.” But my thoughts kept drifting to the email draft open on my laptop, addressed to my mentor. I was supposed to communicate any challenges promptly, and right now, a heated conflict with my project teammates was threatening our deliverable timeline. My mentor expected honesty and transparency, but if I took the time to explain everything now, I’d lose precious minutes I needed for calls. My heart pounded as I weighed the pressure from both sides—my mentor’s trust on one hand, my team’s financial future on the other. I felt trapped, torn between the urge to reach out for help and the demand to keep dialing, each role pulling me in a different direction.
